Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Raman Spectrometer for Research and Training at the University of Mississippi
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, the University of Mississippi will acquire a Raman spectrometer. Raman spectroscopy has become an integral analytical tool in academic chemistry departments, in industry, and in forensic laboratories for the analysis of materials and for basic and applied research. The instrument uses a laser to interact and scatter light from the material to produce a spectrum. The spectrum provides basic information on the composition and structure of the material in a sample. The instrument will be employed in their research by graduate and undergraduate students. It will be incorporated into undergraduate laboratory classes and a Forensic Science program to train students with modern equipment. Students from at least four Mississippi Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs) and Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) will use this advanced analytical instrumentation. The institution will become a regional resource for researchers in need of the technique.

The award is aimed at enhancing research in areas such as (a) elucidating effects of weak noncovalent interactions on biological building blocks; (b) characterizating newly developed nanomaterials including solar cell building blocks, catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction, new organic semiconductor, and gold nanoparticles; (c) developing admicellar polymerization synthetic techniques; (d) studying the effects of carbon dioxide uptake into carbonaceous materials; and (e) studying ionic liquids and their intermolecular interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF MRI grant provided funding for the purchase of a Horiba Scientific LabRAM HR Evolution Raman Microscope system for the University of Mississippi (Ole Miss) Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry for teaching, training, and scientific research.  The acquisition of this scanning microscope system significantly enhanced the University of Mississippi's resources for basic science research and training.  The instrument serves as the centerpiece for the molecular spectroscopy laboratory located on the first floor in the newly-constructed research expansion in Coulter Hall on the campus of the University of Mississippi in Oxford, Mississippi.

Raman spectroscopy has become an integral research tool in academic chemistry departments, in industry, and in forensic laboratories for the analysis of materials and for basic and applied research.  This instrument is used each year to train over forty undergraduate and graduate students in this important analytical spectroscopic technique.  The instrument is also employed to study the vibrational spectroscopic and fluorescence emission properties of newly-developed materials designed for a variety of different applications.  These applications include the development of new sensitizer dyes for solar cells, the creation of new catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting and carbon dioxide reduction, the development of supramolecular architectures based on halogen bonding interactions, the elucidation of molecular-level interactions in biologically-relevant aqueous systems, assigning the vibrational modes of new chemical architectures, and the creation of new energy storage materials based on biochar.
